Brother Robert drew a thin rope out from under the front of
his robes and slid it off over his head. At the end of the
rope hung a gold colored medallion. He shifted the medallion
to reveal a small key. Without removing it from the rope, he
walked over to a small desk and opened a side drawer, then
pulled a small thin book from it and handed it to Ryan.
"We don’t leave this one on the shelves. It would hurt him
too much to see it."
It looked like a children’s book. A beautiful illustration
covered the entire front of the book, a gold border around
the edge. In it stood a boy around his own age with dark eyes
and dark skin, his arm around the waist of the girl he’d
recognized in the painting. He ran his fingers over the
title. The font was an elaborate jumble of calligraphy his
dyslexic brain didn’t even attempt to decipher.
"What is this?"
"Have you heard the tale of the lost prince
and princess?" Brother Robert asked.
Ryan looked up. "As a matter of fact, I have. I fell into
this world around the spot where they died. But didn’t that
happened forever ago?"
Brother Robert nodded toward the book. "The prince
didn’t die."
Ryan thought for a moment. His stomach turned a little and
he rubbed his face with his hands, realization dawning.
"When did this happen?"
"It’s been eighteen years. At the climax of the
General’s so-called Revolution." Brother Paul answered.
Ryan held the book up facing the friars and tapped the girl
in the image. "What if I told you the princess didn’t
die either?"

onchain_metadata.name: Blade of Baz
onchain_metadata.author: Jillian Plomin
Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?

Full chapter tokens grant access to exclusive Discord channels.
onchain_metadata.name: Blade of Baz
onchain_metadata.author: Jillian Plomin
book synposis: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?
Section 1 preview: Prologue:
When the world was newborn and the sun kissed
its face for the first time, a tree grew where its fiery
lips had touched. That tree grew, and as it grew its trunk
split in twain. In time, the tree began to produce fruit.
From the trunk that had grown eastward, a sweet, fleshy,
sunset-orange fruit ripened. The western trunk bore a firm,
crisp, violet fruit. After the first full turning of the
world, the fruits fell.
But before the first orange fruit touched the ground it
transformed into a woman, tall and beautiful.  At the very
same moment a purple fruit fell, changing into a young man,
solid and strong. They knew at once that they were sister
and brother, and they called themselves Orla and Baz.
Together they gathered the rest of the fruit into their
flowing robes. When all the orange and purple fruits were
collected, they breathed on them one by one, and as they
did so, each fruit became a new creature. Some became men
and women like themselves, though not quite as large or
beautiful as themselves. And some became animals. Lions,
falcons and doves, rabbits, bears, fish of all kinds,
wolves, horses, goats, deer, and all manner of insects were
given life and named by the twins Baz and Orla.

Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of

token 10 preview: "It’s too quiet," Erica said.
"It’s always like that at the double moon," Lidian said.
"The daytime creatures have all gone to sleep, but it’s as
if the sky’s still too bright for the owls and nightingales
to come out and play."
The eerie moonlight reflected in the stream, and Erica’s eyes
followed it deeper into the forest. She stood up suddenly,
peering into the woods beyond. "Did you see that?" Erica
said. Tom and Lidian instinctively followed Erica’s gaze.
"What?" asked Lidian, "I don’t see anything."
"That." Erica pointed. Several yards downstream a sudden
movement caught the attention of all three of them. Squinting,
Erica could make out the outline of a web of antlers, and a
colossal stag’s head shot up, staring back at them, eyes like
lamplights echoing the light of the moons. Erica marched
briskly toward it and for a moment it stood stock-still.
Lidian turned to Tom. "Is that a deer, or—"
"No." Tom said, and began jogging after Erica. Catching
up to her, he seized her arm, startling her.
"What?"
"That’s a peryton."
"I know. I’ve seen one before. Maybe this same one." Erica
peered at the creature, its wings flittering as it stared at
her forebodingly. "Do you think it could be following us?"
"I don’t know," Tom replied, "but people say they’re
a bad omen. They can be dangerous."

Ryan woke abruptly, cold and dripping wet. He was lying on a
rough, hard surface. When he lifted one hand to wipe his eyes
the other came with it; he realized they were bound together.
What’s happening? As alertness returned to him, he became
acutely aware of a searing pain around his neck. He opened his
eyes. Sunlight streaked through bars. He was in an enclosed
space, and it was swaying. It was wooden. And there were people
glaring ominously down at him. All of them wore plain gray
regimentals, and some sat stiffly in armor overtop of this. One
of these guards, a stern looking woman with a rather large
bucket in her hands, loomed over him. He deduced that she was
the reason he was suddenly cold, wet, and awake.
"Morning, Sunshine," the woman said. "I have
a few questions for you."
Ryan hesitated. His head throbbed in time to his heartbeat,
which was growing steadily faster. He squinted up at the woman,
but could not make out her face. Daylight streamed in from
behind her, making it impossible for Ryan to make out
much more than a silhouette.
"Who are you?" asked the woman.
"I was just about to ask you that," Ryan said. The woman
kicked him hard in the gut. "Ryan," he spluttered, and
as he drew his knees to his chest, he realized his ankles
were bound as well. He racked his brain for a way to maneuver
out of his restraints, but the pulsating pain in his head
would not allow him to think clearly.
As if reading his muddled mind, the woman said, "Don’t try
any of your fancy tricks. You have several swords on you.
Including the one you’ve stolen." She had swapped the bucket
with a soldier sitting on a wooden bench along the side of
the wagon for the Blade of Baz. She turned it over
in her hands, examining it point to pommel. "Where
did you get this?"
Seeing as he was barely holding on to consciousness, Ryan
abandoned any attempt of being clever, and resigned himself
to the simplest possible truth. "I found it. In my house."
"And where is that?"
"That is literally what I’ve been trying
to figure out for days," Ryan groaned. And, seeing he’d
invited another kick, he spluttered, "I’m lost, okay?
I don’t know where my home is from here."
"Let’s start with something simple." The woman crouched
down by him now, and Ryan could see that she was younger
than he’d expected by several years. Piercing dark eyes
and smooth skin, she couldn’t have been more
than twenty-five. Even so, it was evident she commanded
this space. "Do you come from Aulmagne, or Gaeltach?"
"Neither."
"Don’t test me, boy."
"Look, lady. I’m from New York, in a country
called America, in a world with one moon.
I found that sword in a closet, and the next thing I know,
I’m at the bottom of a ravine between
Aulmagne and Gaeltach,
and I’ve been trying to find a way home ever since."

Cosima was airborne for several seconds as the wagon rolled
out of control. She flailed, hands groping for something to
hold onto, but found nothing. She felt herself thrown through
the air several feet before hitting the expansive, droopy
branches of a pine tree, then rolling haphazardly to the
ground. It took another couple of minutes for her vision to
clear and the world to stop spinning. Then she lay there,
still and numb. She didn’t want to move. It was quiet and
peaceful in this bit of woods. Her first concern, when she
finally let herself have a thought, was for the horses. I
hope they broke free. They were so beautiful. Her second
thought was a resolution: I am not dying today.
Cosima was about to attempt to lift her head when she heard
something crashing through trees and underbrush toward her.
A familiar voice said, "Over here!" Branko. Cosima closed
her eyes. She was grateful for the rescue, and absolutely
mortified to be seen in so weak a state. Faces appeared over
her, blocking out the rising moon’s light.
"Go. Away."

Sister Eirny led them through the doors as she spoke, into a
large circular room, the ceiling of which opened to the dusky
sky, the stars just starting to appear one by one. New
carpentry work had clearly been done, and though the fresh
wood was clearly distinguishable from the older wood, the
architecture matched perfectly. The room was filled with
benches that all faced the center of the room where a statue,
several feet tall, loomed over them. It was a sculpture of a
rather voluptuous woman draped in robes on a comparatively
short pedestal, with curly hair pulled back slightly and
tumbling all the way to her hips. The statue had clearly
been damaged. One of the woman’s arms had broken off as
well as some toes, the nose was missing, many tiny cracks
ran along her right side and there were several chunks of
stone missing in random spots. The entire sculpture looked
as though it had seen a lot of abuse
from the weather as well.

section 2 preview: "So as I understand it, you found a sword that transported you
here when you both had hold of it? Hm. That sounds…magical."
"Pretty much, yeah. It’s crazy, I know."
"Not crazy, but…rare, certainly. Do you still have this
enchanted sword?"
"Yeah, I have it right over here." Ryan retrieved the sword
from the den and brought it to Owen, whose eyes grew into
saucers at the sight of it.
Owen stared, incredulous. "Do you have any idea what this is?"
"No, I just said that. We literally found it in a wall
yesterday."
"I think…I think that could be the Blade of Baz," he murmured
the words with reverence. "I’ve seen artwork depicting it
throughout the ages. It’s absolutely stunning. May I?" Owen
held out his hand and Ryan gave him the sword.
Owen cradled the blade and hilt on his fingertips, examining
the markings that ran along the blade.
"It’s just as the books describe it. Amazing…"
"So…you know something about this thing?" Ryan asked.
"It’s a legendary piece of weaponry, to be sure, passed down
a line of Kings throughout all of Gaeltach’s history…would
you like to hear the Legend of the Blade of Baz?"
Ryan scratched his head and shot a sideways glance at Erica.
"Uh, I guess, sure."
Owen grinned as he moved to stand in front of the twins,
almost like a performer on a stage.
"In the days of The First War, Queen Meda of Gaeltach traveled
through the treacherous mountains on the western border of the
country, bearing with her three carts pulled by six unicorns.
The carts were full of gold, silver, and jewels. They were gifts
for the King of the Goblins that ruled in the land beyond the
mountains.
"When Queen Meda arrived in the court of the Goblin King, she
was welcomed with a grand banquet. After three days and three
nights of festivities, the Queen had beguiled the Goblin King
with her soft voice and piercing eyes, and the Goblin King was
so taken with her that he offered to grant her any request. The
Queen asked for a weapon stronger and more powerful than any in
Gaeltach, that she may bring it back as a gift for her husband
Baz. The Goblin King happily obliged, for in the land of the
Goblins lie metals stronger than any other known in the world,
and the artisans and steelsmiths of the Goblins are unsurpassed
in skill."
"The Goblin King, desiring to impress Queen Meda, charged his
best bladesmith to forge a blade the like of which had never
before been created, and he took some of the jewels the Queen
had brought from Gaeltach to be embedded in the hilt, so as to
be forever known as belonging to the land of the Gaels. The
bladesmith worked many days to produce the gift the Queen would
bestow to her King, and when she offered it to Baz he was
greatly pleased."
At that, Owen’s expression changed from a far off look,
to an expectant one.
"That was…" Ryan searched for the right word,
"Poetic."
Then, steering the conversation back on course,
Ryan said, "So…Is there any chance this thing
can get us back to New York?"
"Well to start, I don’t know that there’s any chance it
brought you here. I’ve read a hundred history books that
mention the Blade of Baz, yet never any mention of
enchantment. There is a tremendous tale about when it was
lost, as well, and a great many accounts of famous deaths
it has caused. But, there’s nothing written about this
sword to indicate it has the power to transport people.
Also, I’m not familiar with this land, New York.
You must have traveled very far indeed."

onchain_metadata.name: Blade of Baz
onchain_metadata.author: Jillian Plomin
synposis: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?
section 3 preview: Cosima smoothed the creamy pomade along her hairline, taming
the last few flyaways in her tightly woven braid. There, she
thought to herself, not a hair out of place. She paused to
appraise her reflection in the floor length mirror in front
of her. She pulled the hem of her uniform jacket taut,
banishing even the slightest hint of a wrinkle, and smoothed
her hands down her front and sides for good measure. Finally,
she gave her reflection a self-satisfied nod, turned on her
heel, and briskly walked to the door, grabbing her satchel
from the side table without breaking stride.
The General’s private offices were on the opposite side of
the fortress, and her meticulous grooming had cost her more
time than she had budgeted. Cosima quickened her pace,
slowing only a fraction of a second to return the salutes of
her subordinates, all of whom halted mid-march to offer them,
resuming their work only once she had passed completely. She
paused outside the main door to the General’s private offices
to take a deep breath. His impudent secretary can not think
she had rushed.
She rapped on the door. "Come in, Ambassador," the
secretary’s voice rang out.

onchain_metadata.name: Blade of Baz
onchain_metadata.author: Jillian Plomin
Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?
section 4 preview: Chapter Seven
Midwood
The next morning a thick fog wafted over the forest, causing
Ryan, Erica, and Owen to sleep well past sunrise. By the time
the camp was packed, however, the fog was nothing more than
thin wisps, and the three travelers set out on the final leg
of the journey.
By mid-morning they had reached an orchard and the sun’s
warmth gleamed on the bright red apples. "We’ll stop here
for a quick breakfast," Owen said. "I’m sure we can get
something more substantial when we get to town." They each
filled their pockets, as well as Owen’s leather bag, and one
more in each hand besides, to eat while they walked.
"Are you sure you want to continue on with that pack?" Owen
asked Erica. Ryan had carried Owen’s pack the day before as a
small way of repaying him for guiding them to a town, and Erica
insisted on doing it today.
"“I’m fine," she said. "Honestly, it’s not nearly as heavy
as I thought it’d be."
After another hour or so walking, with the sun beaming
directly overhead, the forest finally began to thin and they
approached a little farm town. Men and women pushed carts
down a cobblestone street, small hut-like houses lining either
side, each with a robust garden and often a shed and fenced in
pasture with animals grazing.
As Owen, Ryan, and Erica entered the main road, two things
happened at once. First, children trickled out of doors and
yards, running toward them, many throwing their arms around
Owen—clearly he was a favored visitor. Second, one by one the
adults stopped their work and stared at Ryan and Erica, many
gaping as if they’d seen a ghost.

onchain_metadata.name: Blade of Baz
onchain_metadata.author: Jillian Plomin
Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?
section 5 preview: "Um, are we actually in some sort of danger here?" Erica
wondered aloud, a look of sudden alarm passing between brother
and sister as they were helplessly pulled along.
Tom opened a wooden hatch that butted up to the back wall of
the hut and led into darkness. Owen quickly led the way down
the rough wood steps, Ryan and Erica followed, and Tom brought
the hatch back down over his head as he descended the steps.
As their eyes adjusted to the sudden dimness, Ryan and Erica
realized they were in a sort of cellar. Barrels and boxes,
mostly empty, and a wide array of gardening tools were stacked
neatly along the walls. A torch stood in a rusty bracket next
to the doorway they’d just entered through and Tom plucked it
up, pulling a flint from his pocket at the same time. The torch
lit easily and Tom put his hand up to it to prevent sparks
landing on the wooden boxes and barrels.
Owen ran his finger along the back wall muttering to himself,
"Where is it, where is it? Ah!" He shifted a teetering tower
of boxes, knelt down where the boxes had been, and pushed
against what looked like solid dirt wall. After a few seconds
of leaning his shoulder against it, the wall gave way and sank
inward to reveal an opening about three feet high and two feet
wide.
Ryan whooped, "A hidden passageway?! So cool!"
"This is getting freaky." Erica said, her anxiety
growing by the minute.

onchain_metadata.name: Blade of Baz
onchain_metadata.author: Jillian Plomin
Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?
section 6 preview: Tom finished tightening the billet strap of the saddle.
"I'll be right back," said Tom, and he handed the reins
to a girl next to him and took off at a jog back toward the
Channings. "Where is he going? Where are we going?" Ryan
wondered aloud.
The crowd of townsfolk around them was growing by the minute.
Voices chattered one over another in a cacophony of tears and
excitement and fear. A mother took Ryan's hand and tearfully
thanked him for rescuing her child. An angry looking circle
of men and women kept to the edge of the crowd, grumbling to
themselves. The man who had joined the fray with his
slingshot led a group of people in a raucous ballad. It was
all too much for Erica, and even Ryan was becoming flustered
and lost as to what was happening around them.
"Okay, okay, STOP!" Erica held her hands over her ears and
the noise of the crowd around her abated somewhat.
"The Lady wishes to speak!" said one of the men who had
been singing, and he put his hand up in the air for silence.
Suddenly all eyes were on Erica, and now she felt blood rush
to her cheeks. She didn't like being in the spotlight like
this. It was bad enough that she already stuck out like a
sore thumb around here.
"Okay. Look. I don't really know what happened here—"
"You've riled up the Chancellor's men, that's what!
There'll be hell to pay for it, mark my words!"
"Quiet down, you churl—" All at once arguments
arose all over the place.

onchain_metadata.name: Blade of Baz
onchain_metadata.author: Jillian Plomin
Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?
section 7 preview: Ryan and Erica protested staying in the underground bunker
while the others finished preparing for the journey, but it
was no use. The Channings insisted that more soldiers would
come and this time they’d be looking for them. Erica paced
the floor, arms tightly folded, as she silently turned over
all the possibilities in her mind. She considered sneaking
away without the band of rebellious villagers that had globbed
onto them. Restless, she started up her phone again to use
a compass app, but it wouldn’t even load.
Ryan, however, sat on a wooden box, leaning against the dirt
wall, eyes closed in a meditative daze.
"How can you just sit there?" Erica upbraided him, kicking
the box. "Aren’t you at all worried about what we’re getting
ready to do?"
"Nope," he said, eyes still closed.
"I will never understand you," Erica mumbled, crossing her
arms like a petulant toddler as she resumed pacing.
"Worrying gets us nowhere. We have no idea where we are or
what we’re doing. We need these people to help us. I can only
hope they know what they’re doing."
"I don’t trust them. And they look to me to call the shots?
When you and I clearly know less about whatever is going on
than anyone else here? That’s weird."
"Yeah. That is weird."
The door creaked open and Tom popped his head in. In his
quiet brooding state earlier, he had seemed older than he
really was. Now that they were embarking on a real journey,
he looked every bit the child that he still was, eyes wide
with anxious anticipation. Erica felt a sympathetic tug at
her heart. She felt unready, too.
"Time?" Ryan asked. Tom only nodded.
When they pushed open the door to the outside, only
the moon shed any light to see by. Four horses with loaded
saddle bags stood in front of them. Owen was already
mounted on a large bay stallion that pulled at his bit,
clearly itching to stretch his legs. Tuck swung his right
leg up and over the back of a chestnut mare, settling
himself behind Lidian, who held the reins loosely in her
left hand. Tom gently ruffled the ears of a small black
colt, palming a bit of carrot at his mouth and testing the
saddle straps. The fourth horse, a sleek bay filly, pawed
at the ground as she waited for her riders.

onchain_metadata.name: Blade of Baz
onchain_metadata.author: Jillian Plomin
Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?
section 8 preview: Chancellor Ulrich immediately recognized the resonant
click-clacking noise of steel on stone that reverberated down
the long, cavernous hall leading to the secluded study he now
occupied. There was only one person brazen enough to enter his
private apartments unannounced. The footsteps grew louder and
louder, then stopped abruptly, followed by a rap on the door.
"Come in," Ulrich said, without bothering to look up from the
documents he was analyzing. The heavy wooden door behind him
creaked open, and an austere young woman in a drab gray uniform
entered, carrying a stack of missives.
"You leave your back to the door when an unknown person enters?
I could have been an assassin, dagger in your side in an
instant," the woman said, "You should be more careful."
"Your uncommon footwear gives you away, my dear Ambassador,"
Ulrich said still puzzling over his papers, "Besides, you’re
just the person to consult regarding the issue at hand. Come,
Cosima. Have a look."
"I come bearing updates on the soldier training initiative from
General Senaldo." As she spoke she casually walked into the
room toward the Chancellor. Her long, fur-lined woolen coat was
fitted to her diminutive but sturdy frame and billowed to and
fro with the swing of her hips. Taller than the average Gael
and boosted another four inches by the solid steel heels of her
tall boots, Cosima met the Chancellor—and every other man she
interacted with—eye to eye.

onchain_metadata.name: Blade of Baz
onchain_metadata.author: Jillian Plomin
Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
the Aulmagnian people, upsetting the tyrannical rule of
Chancellor Ulrich. Will Ryan and Erica ever make it home,
or are they trapped in this world forever?
section 9 preview: Dawn broke with the sweet smell of dew wafting on the breeze.
Cosima cinched the girth on a tall bay horse absentmindedly
and looked out the wide open barn doors at the pale horizon.
"What are you smiling at?" Lieutenant Branko’s voice was
gruff. He slowly sipped coffee from a tin cup and rubbed his
"Dawn feels different here, don’t you think? It even smells
different." Cosima patted the bay horse and rounded to the
chestnut one on the other side.
"Let the soldiers handle the horses, Cosima. Doesn’t rank
"I love hitching up the horses." Cosima pulled bits of
carrot from a pocket and offered it to the bay horse, stroking
its muzzle. The second horse nudged her greedily. "Yes, I
have some for you, too." She chuckled and let out a sigh as
she nestled her head against the chestnut’s strong neck and
ran her fingers through its silky mane. "They’re the only

Blade of Baz is the first book from Project Bookworm.
This token gives you a preview of the story.
Mint the full token with audiobook for the rest of the section.
Project Bookworm is releasing one section per epoch from
Blade of Baz, by Jillian Plomin.
Collect the whole book to receive a signed special
edition hard copy when the book is printed, and admission
to our special event at cNFTcon in Las Vegas October 7-9
and Rare Bloom in Denver October 14-15.
A warm breeze made Erica’s skirt and sleeves billow. She could
taste salt in the air. The castle in the sea. A chill of
excitement that she wasn’t expecting ran through her.
What will we find there? Clues to a way back home? Maps
to some sort of Einstein-Rosen bridge? Erica’s excitement
gradually spiraled toward anxiety. If we do find a way home,
how do I find Ryan again? Is he even still alive? Can I
save him?
She shook her head vigorously, as though she were trying to
fling the negative thought out of her brain, and refocused
,her mind on polishing her sabers.

Story overview: Ryan and Erica are typical high school students—or so they
think. They have hobbies and homework and friends, and are
generally normal siblings. But one October evening, they
find a curious object that rips them from their cozy suburban
home into a world of rebels, royals, legends, and swords. The
pair now have to find their way back from the strange land of
Aulmagne, but in doing so they ignite chaos and rebellion in
